title: Quad scull
text:
A quadruple sculling boat, often simply called a quad and abbreviated 4x, is a <a href="rowing%20boat">rowing boat</a> used in the <a href="rowing%20%28sport%29">sport of competitive rowing</a>. It is designed for four persons who propel the boat by <a href="sculling">sculling</a> with two <a href="Oar%20%28sport%20rowing%29">oars</a>, or "sculls", one in each hand.
Racing boats (often called "shells") are long, narrow, and broadly semi-circular in cross-section in order to reduce drag. They usually have a fin towards the rear, to help prevent roll and yaw. Originally made from <a href="wood">wood</a>, shells are now almost always made from a <a href="composite%20material">composite material</a> (usually <a href="carbon-fiber%20reinforced%20plastic">carbon-fiber reinforced plastic</a>) for strength and weight advantages. The riggers in sculling apply the forces symmetrically to each side of the boat. Quad sculls is one of the classes recognized by the <a href="International%20Rowing%20Federation">International Rowing Federation</a> and the <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympics</a>. FISA rules specify minimum weights for each class of boat so that no individual will gain a great advantage from the use of expensive materials or technology.
When there are four rowers in a boat, each with only one sweep oar and rowing on opposite sides, the combination is referred to as a "<a href="coxed%20four">coxed four</a>" or "<a href="coxless%20four">coxless four</a>" depending on whether the boat has a <a href="coxswain">cox</a>. In sweep oared racing the rigging means the forces are staggered alternately along the boat. The symmetrical forces in sculling make the boat more efficient and so the quadruple scull is faster than the coxless four. *Update Required*
A 'quad' is different from a 'four' in that a 'quad', or quadruple scull, is composed of four rowers each with two blades, sculling. A 'four' is made up of four rowers each with one oar in hand, sweeping.
